### The Decentralized FDA (dFDA): Amazon for Clinical Trials + Yelp for Every Pill

The current FDA is Soviet central planning: One committee in Maryland decides what 335 million Americans can try. Takes 17 years, costs $2.2 billion, everyone dies waiting.

- New drug approvals dropped 70% overnight (whoops)

- Timeline: 2-3 years ‚Üí 17 years to market
- Life expectancy gains slowed by more than half
- Before 1962: 144,000 doctors ran real-world trials
- After 1962: 200 bureaucrats pretending to be god

- **Treatment Rankings**: Enter your condition and see all treatments ranked by real-world effectiveness
- **One-Click Join**: Click "Try This Treatment" from your doctor's iPad during your appointment
- **Open Source**: Anyone can build on it

**The Payment Revolution**:

- Old FDA trials: Pharma burns $48,000 per patient

Cost per patient: $500 (competition) vs $41,000 (monopoly)
Time to results: 2 years (markets) vs 17 years (bureaucracy)
Patient access: 100% (integrated) vs 15% (gatekept)

It's literally Amazon but for cures. Same convenience, same competition, same customer obsession - but instead of buying crap you don't need, you're buying years of life.

### The DIH: Free Markets Beat Central Planning (Even in Science)

The NIH is literally Soviet science:

- A central committee of 200 reviewers pretends to know all human knowledge.
- $48 billion is allocated by politics, not results.
- A 90% rejection rate means most good ideas die in committee.
- Scientists spend 60% of their time writing grant proposals, not doing science.

The DIH replaces this broken system with a simple, market-based approach. Instead of a committee picking winners, the DIH treasury directly subsidizes patients in the dFDA marketplace, letting them choose which trials to fund.

This unleashes the power of decentralized decision-making:

- **Wisdom of Crowds**: Millions of patients and their doctors deciding is smarter than 200 bureaucrats guessing.
- **Real Competition**: The best treatments attract patients and funding. 
- **No Gatekeepers**: If patients are willing, a trial can get funded. Data and patient demand (not politics) pick the winners.
- **Pay for Success**: Researchers are rewarded for running trials that attract patients and deliver results, not for writing grant proposals.

America spent $41,000 per patient on paperwork. Saved a million documents.

## The Conclusion

Listen: Humanity spends $118.8 trillion a year on war and disease.

That's $14,850 per human per year on suffering.

We're asking for 1% of the military budget. One percent. To cure the diseases that are going to kill you, your parents, your children, and everyone you've ever loved.

The military will still have 99% of its budget. That's enough to end the world 66 times instead of 67.

This isn't liberal or conservative. It's not capitalism or socialism. It's math.

We can keep building bombs until the sun explodes, or we can cure cancer.

We can keep treating symptoms until everyone's bankrupt, or we can eliminate disease.

We can keep being the stupidest species in the universe, or we can try something else.

The people in charge aren't evil. They just like money. So we're going to change what makes the most money. We're going to make saving lives more profitable than ending them.

This isn't just another policy proposal. This is the only realistic path to transcending our natural state of barbarism and fully realizing the magnificent potential of the gifts we've been given: consciousness, reason, and love. We can remain slaves to a system designed for scarce resources and stone axes, or we can rewrite the code of civilization itself.

The choice is binary: Continue our death march toward mutual annihilation, or redirect a mere 1% toward universal flourishing.
